item.title: Threads of Time introduces Luna, Rin, and Bo
item.content:encoded:
• PC
  • Xbox Series

Meet some of the game's time-leaping heroes.

Publisher Humble Games and developer Riyo Games have released new information for turn-based RPG Threads of Time introducing time-leaping heroes Luna, Rin, and Bo.

Here are the details:

In Threads of Time, the characters you meet come from varying points in time and all walks of life. You‚Äôve got warriors, mages, heroes with animal-like characteristics, and so much more. Riyo Games is excited to reveal a first in-depth look at some of the characters players will be traveling through time with in this highly anticipated JRPG.

When you venture from century to century trying to stop a plot to unravel the past, present, and future, the heroes in Threads of Time are who you‚Äôll rely on. From Luna the apprentice to Rin the kitsune, and even a Viking dino vet named Bo, the party members are the unique backbone of the story that spans millennia.

Luna

Luna comes from the Middle Ages‚Äî1000 A.D. to be exact. The 18-year-old is the Fire Mage apprentice to Fontenay that uses Spark Gloves for weapons and loves herself some fried shrimp. Her theories regarding time magic might sound crazy, but could be the secret to uncovering the threatening plot that looks to undo time itself.

Rin

Rin is one of the futuristic heroes in Threads of Time. From 2400 A.D. she does not look her age of 301. Find this three-tailed kitsune devouring slaying enemies with her signature Katars. The freelance infiltrator can slip between her human and fox form to get anywhere she needs to go and steal any secret she wants to know.

Bo

Prehistory is where Bo resides. The 35-year-old Guardian-class hero hails from 12 million B.C. where by day he is a dinosaur veterinarian and by night he‚Äôs a log-lifting strongman who provides the longhouse with comic relief. Utilizing his Warhammer, his sights are set on saving his dinosaur pals and stopping whatever evil corrupts the timeline.

Threads of Time will be available for consoles, including Xbox Series, and PC via Steam. A release date has yet to be announced.

item.title: Pokemon Pokopia ‚ÄòExtended‚Äô trailer, new details and screenshots
item.content:encoded:
• Switch 2

Build a Pokemon paradise.

The Pokemon Company and developers Game Freak and Koei Tecmo have released a 10-minute trailer, and new information and screenshots for life simulation game Pokemon Pokopia.

Here are the details:

A New Life from the Ground Up

In Pokemon Pokopia, players play as a Ditto that has awoken from a long slumber and transformed to look like a human. Ditto meets the peculiar Professor Tangrowth, who has been living all alone in a place where humans and Pokemon once lived‚Äîand appears to be wearing human tools. Seeing the withered grass and trees, Ditto decides to build the area anew by crafting items and learning moves from other Pokemon, creating a utopia for everyone to live in, one step at a time.

  • ‚ùÆ
  • ‚ùØ

Building the Ideal Space

The player can learn moves from the Pokemon they meet, helping to create habitats where different Pokemon will appear. The moves they learn can also be used for other purposes, such as smashing walls with Rock Smash, adding more greenery with Leafage, going from mountain to mountain in a single leap with Glide, or travelling across water with Surf.

Players can also interact with the Pokemon they meet, including playing jump rope with Bulbasaur‚Äôs vines, having Charmander light fires, or teaming up with lots of Pokemon to build houses to live in.

Pokemon may come to the player with requests for making their environment a more comfortable place to live. Some will even have important requests tied to solving larger problems. Fulfilling these requests will lead to the development of the entire area.

Players can also look forward to switching up their look with different hairstyles or outfits, and crafting items or furniture to personalise their surroundings. Up to four players can also enjoy playing together.

Peculiar Pokemon

In addition to Professor Tangrowth, players will encounter other mysterious Pokemon.

  • Peakychu ‚Äì A pale Pikachu with drooping ears whose fur is a mysterious colour.
  • Mosslax ‚Äì Moss has grown all over this Snorlax‚Äôs body, and it looks as though a flower is blooming atop its head. It must have been asleep for a really long time.
  • Smearguru ‚Äì A Smeargle with vibrant colours splattered across its body. It almost looks like a painter when it uses its tail as a brush.

Pokemon Pokopia is due out for Switch 2 on March 5, 2026.

item.title: ChromaGun 2: Dye Hard launches February 12, 2026 for PS5, Xbox Series, Switch 2, and PC
item.content:encoded:
• PC
  • PS5
  • Switch 2
  • Xbox Series

Console versions to be available physically.

Puzzle first-person shooter ChromaGun 2: Dye Hard will launch for PlayStation 5, Xbox Series, Switch 2, and PC via Steam and Epic Games Store on February 12, 2026, publisher PM Studios and developer Pixel Maniacs announced. The console versions are newly announced, and will be available both physically and digitally.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôve taken everything the fans loved about the original‚Äîthe witty dialogue, the fiendishly clever puzzles, and the saturated aesthetic‚Äîand dialed it up to 11,‚Äù said Pixel Maniacs founder and CEO Benjamin Lochmann in a press release. ‚ÄúDye Hard is bigger, bolder, and requires a level of color coordination and spatial reasoning that will test even the most seasoned puzzle enthusiasts. The team is eager to watch the most insane full game speedruns from the community!‚Äù

PM Studios CEO Michael Yum added, ‚ÄúChromaGun 2: Dye Hard expands the creative spectrum of our portfolio with a bold, brainy experience that stands apart from anything else we‚Äôve launched. We‚Äôre proud to offer a retail edition for a game this inventive‚Äîit‚Äôs something every fan of clever design should want to have as part of their physical collection.‚Äù

Here is an overview of the game, via PM Studios:

About

ChromaGun 2: Dye Hard is a first person puzzle shooter about colors. Players use the titular ChromaGun to paint walls and droids, and droids are magnetically attracted to walls of the same color. Between deadly floor tiles, angry droids, and subtractive color-mixing, players get to solve tricky logic puzzles wrapped in a comedic story about friendship, redemption, and the multiverse.

Key Features

  • A One-of-a-Kind Tool ‚Äì The ChromaGun: Wield the titular ‚ÄúChromaGun,‚Äù a versatile paint-gun used to shoot primary colors onto surfaces and objects, mixing them to manipulate the environment
  • Magnetoid Chromatism ‚Äì Master the key mechanic of ‚ÄúMagnetoid Chromatism‚Äù‚Äîa proprietary concept where Droids and other objects are magnetically attracted to walls of the same color.
  • Multiverse Puzzles ‚Äì Travel through time and space across different dimensions and parallel universes, each introducing new physics and increasingly complex mechanics.
  • State of the Art Accessibility ‚Äì Pixel Maniacs developed a unique accessibility game mode overlaying symbols on colored objects to help color blind players to enjoy the game too! With this well-thought feature, ChromaGun 2: Dye Hard won the ‚ÄúHorizon Award‚Äù for Technical Innovation at GG Bavaria 2025!

item.title: Bo: Path of the Teal Lotus ‚ÄòTanuki Kabuki‚Äô update now available
item.content:encoded:
• PC
  • PS5
  • Switch
  • Xbox Series

New post-game content, including a boss rush mode.

The ‚ÄúTanuki Kabuki‚Äù for Bo: Path of the Teal Lotus is now available, publisher Humble Games and developer Squid Shock Studios announced. It features new post-game content, including a boss rush mode, Tanuki races, collectibles, and quality of life improvements.

‚ÄúWe wanted to celebrate our players‚Äô skill and style by turning combat into performance,‚Äù said Squid Shock Studios creative director Chris Stair in a press release. ‚ÄúThe ‚ÄòTanuki Kabuki‚Äô update is our way of letting players take the stage and showcase their best moves, while also giving them ways to deepen their connection to Bo through fun collectibles and creative expression.‚Äù

  • ‚ùÆ
  • ‚ùØ

Here is an overview of the update, via Humble Games:

The ‚ÄúTanuki Kabuki‚Äù update adds new post-game challenges, gameplay options, and collectibles to the critically acclaimed hand-drawn 2.5D action platformer from Squid Shock Studios.

Completing the base game unlocks the ‚ÄúTanuki Kabuki‚Äù update, the ultimate encore performance, transforming Bo‚Äôs world into a grand stage with a Kabuki-style Boss Rush mode, where players perform each battle before a reactive audience. In Solo Mode, players can pick and choose between individual boss encounters from the main game to replay, while Gauntlet Mode challenges them to face a curated sequence of fights in a single run. Optional Seals modify difficulty for greater rewards, and the audience responds dynamically to each performance, offering higher acclaim for skillful play.

The update also introduces the Tanuki Tracker questline, a post-game adventure where players search for mischievous Tanuki hidden across the world. Once discovered, these Tanuki can be raced in time-based platforming challenges. Emerging victorious unlocks new features inside the Kabuki Theater, including a Combat Rehearsal Room for practicing techniques, a Tanuki Kabuki Band jukebox for listening to music, and Bo‚Äôs Room, a space for displaying furniture and collectibles that players can customize. A new (completely free) gacha machine Bestiary has also been added, featuring 77 collectible dolls representing characters and enemies from across the game, expanding the lore and artistry of Bo‚Äôs world.

Beyond the new content, the ‚ÄúTanuki Kabuki‚Äù update also delivers numerous balance adjustments, accessibility and quality of life improvements, stability updates designed to refine and enhance gameplay . . . and even a few secrets for players to uncover.

Bo: Path of the Teal Lotus is available now for PlayStation 5, Xbox Series, Switch, and PC via Steam.
